title: 108_hr5226
content: SECTION 1. CROP DISASTER ASSISTANCE. In this section, definitions are provided for terms like "additional coverage," "insurable commodity," and "noninsurable commodity" related to agricultural insurance. Emergency financial assistance is also mentioned, overriding a specific section of the Federal Crop Insurance Act. The curr_chunk defines "commodity" as an agricultural product eligible for assistance under a specific act. It authorizes emergency financial assistance for producers facing crop losses due to weather conditions, using funds from the Commodity Credit Corporation. The assistance is administered similarly to another section. The Secretary provides assistance to farms with qualifying crop or quality losses due to damaging weather conditions. Assistance is administered similarly to another section, using the same loss thresholds. Producers are ineligible for assistance if they did not obtain insurance for insurable commodities. Producers on a farm are ineligible for assistance under this section if they did not obtain insurance for insurable commodities or file paperwork for noninsurable commodities by the applicable deadlines. The Secretary has the authority to waive these requirements. Producers must obtain insurance or file paperwork by the State deadline for insurable or noninsurable commodities to be eligible for assistance. The Secretary can waive these requirements if producers enter into a contract agreeing to obtain insurance for the next 2 crops or file paperwork and pay fees for noninsurable commodities. The Act requires producers to obtain insurance or file paperwork by the State deadline for insurable or noninsurable commodities to be eligible for assistance. In case of violation, producers must reimburse the Secretary for the full assistance amount. Payment limitations apply to the assistance provided for losses to a crop. Payment limitations apply to the assistance provided for losses to a crop, with a maximum limit of 95 percent of the crop's estimated value in the absence of losses. This includes crop insurance payments and other specified payments. The Secretary includes crop insurance payments and estimates the value of crops not lost. Assistance under this section is reduced by assistance received from Florida Disaster Programs. The Livestock Assistance Program is outlined in Section 2. The Livestock Assistance Program outlined in Section 2 includes emergency financial assistance for livestock losses in designated counties for either 2003 or 2004. The Secretary of Agriculture will use funds from the Commodity Credit Corporation to administer payments, with a portion allocated for the American Indian livestock program. Assistance will be provided in a similar manner as outlined in the Agriculture, Rural Development, Food and Drug Administration, and Related Agencies Appropriations Act, 2001. The Livestock Assistance Program provides emergency financial assistance for livestock losses in designated counties for either 2003 or 2004. The Secretary of Agriculture will administer payments using funds from the Commodity Credit Corporation, following the guidelines of the Agriculture, Rural Development, Food and Drug Administration, and Related Agencies Appropriations Act, 2001. Producers will not be penalized for actions that reduce their livestock numbers due to disaster conditions. The Tree Assistance Program is outlined in Section 3. The Secretary of Agriculture will use funds from the Commodity Credit Corporation to provide emergency assistance to producers who suffered tree losses between December 1, 2003, and December 31, 2004. Additionally, an extra $15,000,000 will be used to reimburse eligible forest landowners for tree losses during the same period. The Secretary of Agriculture will allocate an additional $50,000,000 from the Commodity Credit Corporation to support the Emergency Conservation Program for participants to receive maximum cost share percentage. The Commodity Credit Corporation funds, facilities, and authorities will be utilized to implement this Act, along with regulations to be established. The Secretary of Agriculture may issue regulations to implement the Act without following certain procedures. Congressional review of agency rulemaking will be conducted under specific authority. SEC. 7. OFFSET. Amends Section 1241(a)(3) of the Food Security Act of 1985 to allocate $6,037,000,000 for fiscal years 2005 through 2014.
